trans-unit.source: Your data will not be saved if you close this page. You can download a report as part of the last step. If you do not want to save your data, you can safely close this page.
Which ILOs are tested with this assessment? Select one or multiple.
Does the potential use of GenAI in the assessment, as listed above, affect the extent to which can be tested?
{VAR_PLURAL, plural, =1 {this learning goal} other {these learning goals}}

In other words, evaluate whether you think can still be tested with the chosen type of assignment, assuming that students will use GenAI in the ways listed above and, potentially, more. If you select ‚ÄòNo‚Äô, your assessment is GenAI resilient. Congratulations! If you select ‚ÄòYes‚Äô, you will be presented some suggestions to make your assessment more resilient.
No adjustments available. Select an assessment form first.
Known AI Uses for this assessment form
No known AI uses available for this assessment form.
Click the bars below to see examples of ways in which students may use GenAI for this assessment form.
In this step, you will receive information on how students can make use of GenAI for the assessments in your course.

After adding an assessment, you decide whether the use of GenAI is a problem in this context, based on the ILOs that are tested. If you consider the use of GenAI in the assessment a problem, the tool suggests alternatives.
Next, pick one or more intended learning outcomes that are assessed in this way and whose assessment could be affected by the use of GenAI.
Please select one type of assessment. You can add more below.
No ILOs available. Add some in the previous step.
üåô Step 3: Rethinking courses in times of GenAI

The previous steps aimed at checking the extent to which your current course design is resilient against the potential use of GenAI. In this third step, you are invited to reconsider exercises or assignments by involving generative AI to various extents. The AI assessment scale that this step is based on, has officially been accepted by the UU as a guiding principle. It helps teachers to think of generative AI in a less binary manner ‚Äì not as something that is either forbidden or approved, but as a set of tools that can be integrated in academic education to different degrees.

Below you will find a scale with five levels of AI integration in educational assessments, based on the AI Index for teachers, as adopted by Utrecht University. Additional information regarding the university policy on generative AI can be found here. (Both links will open in a new tab).
AI Index for teachers (click to enlarge)

Click on one of the five levels to find examples of educational exercises or assignments that make use of generative AI to different degrees (levels 2-5) or not at all (level 1). You can check off examples that you are interested in. These will be included in your final report.
Select the options below that you would like to include in your summary report.
AI Index (Link will open in a new tab.)
Centre for Digital Humanities, Utrecht University
Generative AI - A four-step reflection tool

This application has been developed by Pim Huijnen and Swantje Falcke in collaboration with the Centre for Digital Humanities within the context of the USO project "AI in Higher Education: Building reflective awareness through educational interventions".
You are free to share and adapt the contents of this site, if you give appropriate credit and use it non-commercially. More on Creative Commons.

Welcome to the GenAI reflection tool. This tool is designed to reflect on the impact of GenAI on the learning goals of individual courses. It works best if you run this tool with a particular course in mind (and to have the course manual ready). The tool will guide you through some steps (see below) that challenge you to reflect on the validity of the intended learning outcomes of the course and the effectiveness of the assignments to test these. Once finished, you will be offered a report with an overview of the outcomes.
You can run the tool as many times and for as many courses as you like. We do not store or save the information you enter in this tool.
This tool consists of four subsequent steps:
üåç Step 1: Learning outcomes analysis clarify and map your course goals.
üöÄ Step 2: Assessments assess whether the use of generative AI in assignments negatively impacts the learning outcomes.
üåô Step 3: Rethinking courses in times of GenAI explore how generative AI can be used to enhance your course.
‚ú® Step 4: Report after finishing the tool you can download a report with the most important outcomes.
Please provide the name of your course. This will personalize the final report.
Enter the name of your course...
In this step, you will map the Intended Learning Outcomes (ILOs) for your course and link each one to the most relevant Dublin Descriptor.
Enter the intended learning outcomes of your course here (one per field). You can do this in your own words. For each ILO you enter, please select the Dublin Descriptor that best aligns.
You have completed the GenAI reflection tool! To generate the report, please enter your name and click the button below.
You are welcome to send your own examples of students' GenAI usages to genaitool@uu.nl.
Would you like to share your own examples?
You are welcome to send your own suggestions for adjustments to genaitool@uu.nl.
Would you like to share your own suggestions?
You are welcome to send your own examples for AI usages to genaitool@uu.nl.
Please enter a course name (on the introduction page).
Please enter your name in the field above.
Please enter a course name in the field above.
The Dublin Descriptors are internationally recognized criteria to classify learning outcomes. They are organized into five categories:
